data.title: Drugstore Chains Set To Merge
data.meta_description:
Two drugstore chain giants, Revco D.S. Inc. and Hook-Superx Inc. signed a definitive merger agreement yesterday that would create the nation's second-largest drug chain in terms of total sales and stores. 

Revco agreed to pay $600 million cash for Hook-Superx, or $13.75 a share. The price includes $300 million of Hook debt that Revco will assume.
data.text:
Two drugstore chain giants, Revco D.S. Inc. and Hook-Superx Inc. signed a definitive merger agreement yesterday that would create the nation's second-largest drug chain in terms of total sales and stores.

Revco agreed to pay $600 million cash for Hook-Superx, or $13.75 a share. The price includes $300 million of Hook debt that Revco will assume.

When the merger is completed this summer, Revco will operate 2,367 stores in the Midwest, Southeast and Northeast, and have total sales of $4.54 billion, according to Drug Store News, an industry publication. Shareholders of both companies must still approve terms of the deal.

The Walgreen Company is the sales leader with $8.3 billion in the 1993 fiscal year, while the Rite Aid Corporation is the industry leader in number of stores with 2,689.

In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Hook-Superx, which is based in Cincinnati, closed at $12.75, up $3.625, while Revco shares closed down 62.5 cents, to $15.75. Chains Seeking Partners

Drugstore chains are expanding into new markets or seeking partners to gain market share, something that will be important as health care changes continue.
